subtitle: a guide to the Tibetan Book of the Dead
[Music]
the Tibetan Book of the Dead also known
as the bardrobe
is an ancient text that has its origin
in the Tibetan Buddhist tradition it is
a guide to the intermediate State
between death and rebirth it is read or
recited to someone who is dying or has
recently died in order to help them
navigate the hallucinations and visions
that occur the Tibetan Book of the Dead
offers a unique perspective on the
nature of Consciousness and The Human
Experience of death and rebirth teaching
that Consciousness is not limited to the
body and the death is not an end but
rather a transition to a new state of
being
the Tibetan Book of the Dead Origins can
be traced back to the 8th century when
the Tibetan King Tree song detsen
directed the Indian Buddhist Master
Padma sambhava to bring the teachings of
Buddhism to Tibet Padma sambhava known
also as Guru reponche brought the
teachings on the bardos or the states
between death and rebirth from his
teachers in India the teachings were
later compiled into the text known today
as the Tibetan Book of the Dead however
the book is not considered to be
Buddhist scripture in the traditional
sense
scriptures are texts that are the words
of the Buddha or other enlightened
beings and they are considered to be the
ultimate source of Buddhist teachings
the Tibetan Book of the Dead is
considered to be terma or a hidden
treasure termas are believed to contain
teachings that are specifically suited
for the Tibetan cultural context the
Tibetan Book of the Dead however soon
spread well past its Tibetan cultural
context and across the globe beginning
with its translation into English
the text which was written originally in
tibetan was first translated into
English by W Y Evans Wentz in 1927. it
was later revised and re-translated by
Francesca Fremantle and kugiam trunkpa
in 1975. the text has now been
translated into many languages making it
widely accessible to readers all around
the world the Dalai Lama the spiritual
head of Tibetan Buddhism has said that
the Tibetan Book of the Dead is quote a
very useful guide for everyone on how to
approach death in the period after death
end quote he also emphasized the
importance of the teachings as a source
of inspiration and guidance in everyday
life not just during the process of
dying or after death in the 1960s the
Tibetan Book of the Dead became very
popular with a western counterculture
movement who were attracted to its
teaching on Consciousness and the nature
of reality during this time it inspired
many works of art literature and film
including Pink Floyd's album The Dark
Side of the Moon and the Beatles ground
breaking single Tomorrow Never Knows
from the revolver album we will look at
the Tibetan book of the dense vast
impact on Western culture later in this
video in recent times the Tibetan Book
of the Dead has gained a wider audience
in the west through its incorporation
into practices such as yoga and
meditation
in life you make the mind
what happens when we die physics tells
us that energy cannot be destroyed thus
it is when we die that pattern of energy
that we call mind or Consciousness that
we identify as ourselves continues the
body drops but that person of energy
that is consciousness remains
Consciousness is no longer associated
with the body Consciousness also is no
longer anchored by the body
Consciousness is in a sense floating
free of the body this might at first
glance seem not a bad thing especially
if the body had been diseased or in
terrible pain Tibetan Buddhists however
have a saying quote in life you make the
mind in death the Mind makes you end
quote
what does this mean
that while you were alive with the young
cow the body when you thought something
you were limited on acting or releasing
that thought by the limitation of the
physical body for example if you thought
I would like to be in Paris you would
need to go through the whole process of
getting on a plane Etc now however in
death when Consciousness is loosed from
the body if you think I want to be in
Paris immediately you are in Paris or at
least the dream realm version this might
seem like a lot of fun until you begin
to think of some of the not so great
thoughts you have thoughts that while
alive are slowed in realization by the
physical limit of the body thoughts that
in death will become your reality
instantly
sometimes in Rapid unending exhausting
succession have you ever thought I like
to kill that person now one might begin
to get a sense of the importance that
Tibetan Buddhists put on the
purification of the mind while alive
while you are still anchored by the body
a purification based on gratitude
compassion kindness Loving Thoughts and
the Deep recognition of the inherent
empty ground of Mind in death the mind
is going to make you the Mind forms and
dream Realms that one tends to
experience during the dying process and
after death are formed by the type of
thinking the Mind forms you entertained
or clung to while alive these mind forms
in dream Realms experience during death
and dying by the now bodyless
Consciousness formed during one's
lifetime are called in the Tibetan Book
of the Dead bardos
Bartos are formed by the karmic energies
or repeated thoughts that one
accumulated during their lives the
purpose of the Tibetan Book of the Dead
is to guide you through these bardos but
more than that it is to help you
recognize the unreality of them and thus
become aware of the radiant Primal and
empty Consciousness from which they
arose and to which they will return
the Bartos
the consciousness of the deceased passes
through a series of Bartos that exist
between their death and rebirth this
lasts according to the Tibetan Book of
the Dead for a period of 49 days before
being reborn into another body while
passing through these bardos the
consciousness of the deceased
experiences a series of hallucinations
and Visions these Visions are caused by
the karmic energies that have
accumulated during the individual's
previous lifetimes these Visions can be
either of a positive or negative type
depending on the individual's past
actions in the state they were in at the
time of death the Tibetan Book of the
Dead teaches that the ultimate goal is
to recognize the true nature of these
visions and to let them go in the
primordial ground if the deceased can
recognize and release the Visions
appearing as they pass through the
bardos and they will attain a better
birth and ultimately enlightenment the
Tibetan Book of the Dead is divided into
three main sections
the Bardo of Life the barter of dying
and the Bardo of Dharma Nirvana each of
these sections is further divided into
sub-bardos the describe and map the
various experiences and visions that may
occur during the process of dying after
death and in the process of rebirth the
bottle of life this is the Bardot of
living it includes the present moment
and all of life's experiences it does
not however have any sub-bardos the
Bardo of dying
subpada of the inward experience of
dying subbardo the outward experience of
dying the barter of Darwin Nirvana sub
part of the experience of the clear
light of reality
some part of the experience of the
ground Luminosity it is important to
note that these subpartos are not
necessarily distinct stages that occur
in a linear progression instead there
are different aspects that may arise at
any time during the process of dying
after death or in the process of rebirth
the experience of the borders
what does a person experience in a
bottle according to the Tibetan Book of
the Dead once the Bardo of dying has
begun the person will experience
different qualities of hallucinations or
visions depending whether in the inward
or outward Sabato in the inward Sabato
which often occurs in the initial stages
of dying the person is likely to
experience a sense of peacefulness or
Clarity visions of deities ancestors or
loved ones who have passed away a sense
of Detachment from the body and the
physical world a feeling of lightness or
weightlessness the experiences of the
inward sabado as suggested by the
Tibetan Book of the Dead share many
similarities with those reports known as
ndes or near-death experiences we will
look at some of those similarities in a
moment in the outward subbato which
often occurs in the initial stages of
dying the person is likely to experience
physical Sensations such as he feet cold
pressure or pain
sensations of movement are being pulled
in different directions
sounds or voices that they may hear
beyond the initial subatos of the Inward
and outward is another root Barto the
Bardo of Dharma Nirvana the individual
in this part of may experience a further
variety of hallucinations or visions
depending on whether in the subparto of
clear light of reality or the ground
luminosity in the clear light of reality
they may experience a sense of pure
unmodified consciousness
a sense of unity with all of existence
in the ground Luminosity they may
experience a sense of the primordial
awareness that underlies all of
existence visions of various deities or
Celestial Realms these descriptions are
very generalized each individual's
experience of vibato or sub-bato may be
very different however it is held by the
Tibetan Buddhists and the Tibetan Book
of the Dead the most auspicious stage
and the stage for the greatest chance of
an improved rebirth or even
Enlightenment is while passing through
the Bardo of Dharma Nirvana the Tibetan
Book of the Dead and ndes
near-death experiences ndes are
first-hand reports from people who have
experienced a near-death event such as a
cardiac arrest or a serious accident the
overwhelming reports from ndes is that
the person often experiences a profound
sense of Peace a sense of not being
limited to the body loving encounters
with deceased loved ones or Spiritual
Beings some researchers have noted that
there are striking similarities between
the descriptions of ndes and the bardos
described in the Tibetan Book of the
Dead one of the main similarities
between ndes and the bardos is the sense
of peace and well-being as we have seen
in the Tibetan Book of the Dead the
barter of dying and the border of Dharma
Nirvana can be states of great peace and
Clarity free from suffering and where
one is able to connect with their
enlightened nature similarly many people
who have had ndes report feeling a sense
of profound peace and acceptance during
their experience even if they were
previously experiencing great physical
pain or fear this sense of peace is
often described as being much deeper and
more profound than anything they had
ever experienced in everyday life this
is often accompanied by a sense of being
at one with universe or with God Source
or higher power nde's reports also
describe an experience of Consciousness
expanding beyond the limits of the body
both the bardos of dying and Dharma
Nirvana are described in the Tibetan
Book of the Dead as states where the
individual's Consciousness becomes
detached from the body and experiences
an expansive and Limitless sense of
being nde's report having left their
body and being able to observe the
surroundings from many different
perspectives ndes in the Tibetan Book of
the Dead both report and counters with
deceased loved ones and or Spiritual
Beings these encounters are often
described as being extremely comforting
and reassuring other similarities are
experiencing radiant light a sense of
being outside of time and space a sense
of having access to profound insights
and understanding the altered state of
consciousness experienced during the
death process is often described both by
ndes in the Tibetan Book of the Dead is
being more real and Vivid than everyday
reality and those who have uniquely made
a u-turn back into the Bardo of living
those who have experienced a near-death
experience and not the experience of
death itself return to life and reported
the insights and deep wisdom that they
gained during their near-death
experience has gone on to have
profoundly beneficial impact on the
remainder of their lives this insight
and deep wisdom and profound benefit is
also what is offered by reading of the
Tibetan Book of the Dead
the Tibetan Book of the Dead and Western
culture
the Tibetan Book of the Dead has had a
significant impact on Western culture
many Western artists writers thinkers
and musicians have embraced the book
Because of its insights into the nature
of Consciousness and The Human
Experience a primary Concept in the
Tibetan Book of the Dead is that of ego
death this is the idea that the ego or
sense of separate self is a temporary
and illusory construct that must be seen
as false or unreal in order to achieve
enlightenment it is this idea which
influenced those Western thinkers and
artists on The Tibetan Book of the Dead
is a source of creative inspiration and
guidance one prominent example is
timothilleri this famous controversial
psychologist and counter-culture icon
was best known as a leading advocate of
LSD as a means of achieving spiritual
enlightenment Leary along with Ralph
metzner and Richard Alpert later known
as RAM does use the Tibetan Book of the
Dead is a guide for their research on
LSD and other psychedelics they use the
outlining of vibatos in the Tibetan Book
of the Dead to understand and interpret
what they believed were lsds stripping
away of ego defenses and its inducing
psychological ego death and rebirth the
Tibetan Book of the Dead was not however
nearly used for understanding the
effects of LSD many Western artists
writers and musicians utilize the book
to create works of art here are just a
few examples French composer Pierre
Henry used the text as the basis for his
pioneering 1963 Electro acoustic
balletwork lavoyage released in 1967 for
the late 1960s band the third Bardo took
the name from the Tibetan Book of the
Dead Finnish composer Eric bagman
composed a work titled Bardo thodor in
1974 Philip K Dick's 1969 novel yubik is
inspired with the Tibetan text and
features a direct quote from it by one
of the characters the 1991 book The
Tibetan book of living and dying by
sogyar rupanche is an updated version of
the Tibetan Book of the Dead as recently
as 2017. the American writer George
Saunders released the experimental novel
Lincoln in the Bardo which became a
bestseller and tells the story of
Abraham Lincoln grieving the death of
his son while passing through many of
the bardos described in the Tibetan Book
of the Dead screenwriter and film
producer Bruce Joel Rubin considers his
1990 film Jacob slatter to be a modern
interpretation of the Tibetan Book of
the Dead the 2009 French film Enter the
Void was based on the Tibetan text in
television the popular show Twin Peaks
includes a reference to the Tibetan Book
of the Dead in an episode where a
character is dying and the Tibetan Book
of the Dead continues to have an impact
on Western culture
conclusion
despite its ancient Origins the Tibetan
Book of the Dead is still relevant and
important to read today it provides a
unique perspective on the nature of
Consciousness and The Human Experience
of death and rebirth its teachings
emphasize the importance of recognizing
the true nature of reality and offer
wise guidance on how to navigate the
intermediate State between deaths and
rebirth for those people interested in
exploring spiritual and philosophical
questions about the nature of
Consciousness and the meaning of life
the Tibetan Book of the Dead can provide
profound insight and deep wisdom but
perhaps the most important reason to
read the Tibetan Book of the Dead is a
practical guidance it provides for those
who are facing death or are caring for
someone who is dying the text provides a
detailed map of the experiences and
visions that may occur during the
process of dying and after death it
offers practical guidance and
step-by-step instruction actions on how
to navigate the arising experiences
during the death process this can be
especially helpful for those who are
dealing with a practical and emotional
challenges of caring for someone who is
dying as it can provide a sense of
direction and purpose in the face of
such a difficult time the Tibetan Book
of the Dead is also an important
cultural and literary work this classic
Tech stock Tibetan Buddhism has played a
significant role in the development of
Tibetan culture in spiritual practice
the reading of the Tibetan Book of the
Dead provides invaluable insight into
the history and culture of Tibet as well
as its broader Buddhist tradition the
Tibetan Book of the Dead also emphasizes
the importance of mindfulness and
compassion the text advises the deceased
and the living to cultivate mindfulness
and to cultivate a compassionate
attitude towards all beings thus the
Tibetan Book of the Dead is not merely
guidance for the dead and die
but for the living as well by reading
and taking in its wisdom one will
cultivate a deeper understanding of the
nature of reality while developing a
more compassionate and mindful approach
to life
